line.en: 'Wow, what's this?'
After school, we went to the garage and saw large\namounts of cardboard boxes and tin cans piled up.
'Oh, it's you guys!'
'What is all this?'
'Ah, it finally arrived!'
Before Amane answers, Ageha comes in after us and\nher eyes sparkle as she looks on.
'These are the materials for making the main\nwings. There are still some outside, so could you\ngive me a hand carrying them?'
Then, with a great deal of effort, we carry the\nmaterials.
Ageha goes to check them off against the purchase\norder.
'OK, it's all here.'
'Great.'
'Hee hee hee! With this, we can finally make the\nwings!'
Ageha is extremely enthusiastic.
'What's this big thing here?? It's huge but\nreally light.'
'It's Styrofoam. We use it to make the shape.'
'The length of a single wing is about eight\nmeters. We need quite a large amount to make the\nshape.'
That must be why there are such large amounts of\nthe other materials too.
'Once they're complete, it will be able to fly,\nright? OK, let's start making them right away.'
Kotori is also keen to start, but it's not like\nshe knows how to make them.
'How do we make them? Is it something that we can\ndo here?'

'It's made from FRP, fiber-reinforced plastic, so
I think that we probably won't need any special
equipment. The question is whether we have enough
space or not.'
'Isn't that right, Amane?'
'Yeah. They were made here last time too.'
'But what is that... FRP stuff?'
I'm not familiar with that term.
'It's strengthened plastic. The main wings are\nbuilt from this material.'
'Strengthened plastic...?'
Even as I say it, it still doesn't make sense.
The broken wings are propped against the wall.
They are smooth and hard to the touch.
'I thought it would be made from aluminum or\nsomething.'
'Wouldn't the plastic crack, though?'
asks Kotori as she looks at the broken pieces.
'It's OK. As long as they are properly made.'
'It's strange. I thought I did make them\nproperly.'
Amane goes deep into thought as she too looks at\nthe broken pieces next to Kotori.
'FRP is really sturdy.'
'It's plastic mixed with fiberglass which\nincreases the strength and is based on the same\nidea as reinforced concrete.'
'Reinforced concrete??'
'Well, that's where they put reinforcing iron\nbars through the concrete.'
'Concrete is strong but it weakens if it is\npulled or bent. The iron bars compensate for this\nweakness.'
'FRP is the same. Plastic is strong but lacks\nflexibility and is strengthened by being mixed\nwith fiberglass.'
'I see.'
I'll just go along with it for now.
I'm not sure if I understand or not.
As for the finer details, we'll probably learn\nthose in class sooner or later. That's the kind\nof school it is.
'Why is FRP used instead of iron or aluminum?'
'There are several advantages but when it comes\nto making gliders, it must be the most suitable\nmaterial.'
'That's right. At present, FRP is a common\nmaterial used to make gliders.'
'Of course, metal is strong but making it from\nplastic reduces the weight.'
'It's easy to process, cheap, it can be repaired\nlater and does not corrode.'
Amane agrees with each point with a nod.
'By the way, you might be surprised that FRP is\nalso used in some things that are very familiar.'
'Hmm... what could those be?'
'The bumpers of cars, and the hull of fishing\nboats, apparently.'
'The pedal boats at the park, and also the\nColonel statue outside that Kentucky shop.'
As she mentions the Colonel, Kotori and I nod in\nagreement.
I've touched the Colonel statue many times and\nalso had silly photos taken next to it with my\nfriends from the Cycle Racing Club.
So that's FRP, huh?
'So the glider is made from the same material as\nthe Colonel...?'

Kotori murmured but I wasn't sure if she was
happy because she felt the glider was somehow
more familiar than she realized, or because her
dream was shattered just a little.
'How exactly do we make them?'
'Oh, yes. To explain it simply...'
'First, you make the shape of the wings. Then,\nit's covered with FRP.'
'We begin with this...'
Ageha opens one of the boxes that had just\narrived, and pulls out some sort of cloth.
'We line it with this glass mat. This is the\nfiberglass we were talking about just now.'

'Then, the resin is spread on top of it, then
another layer of fiberglass is laid out, then we
spread more resin... and repeat that a few
times.'
'After that, we wait for it to dry, then take it\noff...'
'And it's complete?'
'No, not yet. Once the surface has been polished\nand painted, it's finished.'
'Sounds easy.'
'Well that's because that's how it is in a\nnutshell.'
'Actually, there are many more steps.'
'When making something this big, there are cases\nwhere the usual methods don't work.'
'Well, let's take it one step at a time. Amane,\ncould you show me the plans?'
As Ageha takes a look at the plans, she and Amane\nstart discussing something.
'Hmm, hmm... I see... It looks like we have no\nchoice but to split it here and then join it\nlater...'
'But if we do that, we'll have problems with the\nweight. If it's too heavy...'
The conversation moves on to things that we don't\nunderstand.
'Amane, when it comes to making the main wings,\ndo you think you could leave it to me?'
'Sure, I don't mind.'
'...It would be better than me making it, right?'
'Thank you! Kotori...'
Kotori is surprised to hear her name called out\nall of a sudden.
I think it's about time for them to start being\nmore friendly towards each other but...
'Y...yes, what is it?'
'You can help too, Kotori.'
'Of course, that's what I was planning to do.'
'I'll help too.'
'Hmm...we only really need you when we need an\nextra pair of hands. You should make the\nsimulator your priority.'
Kotori gives me an uneasy glance.
'I'll leave it to you two then.'
'Oh...yes, leave it to us.'
With that, Ageha became the one in charge of\nmaking the main wings, and then got to work on\nmaking them.
'OK, let's do this the way we were taught.'
'First...make the shape using the Styrofoam...'
'However, the polyester resin melts the\nStyrofoam, so before we use that, it needs to be\ncoated...'
Until just now, Kotori had been taking Ageha's\nimpromptu FRP course.
She had been seriously taking notes, and reads\nthem back as they proceed with the work.
By the way, for now, it's just practice, so they\nare trying to make something not related to the\nmain wings.
'We begin with laying out the fiberglass, and\napply the polyester resin with a roller...'
'Oh, that's no good. You have to roll it in more\nfirmly.'
'I...I am.'
'When you get to the corner, use a brush. Don't\napply too much resin.'
'I know that, geez, shut up...'
'If we leave bubbles, it will create cavities,\nand that will cause it to become weaker.'
'If that happens, they will break, again.'
As Amane stood beside me, teaching me about\npiloting, she seemed to have a hurt expression on\nher face.
'...Are you OK, Amane?'
'Yeah, I'm fine...'
she answered, still with that hurt look about\nher.
It seems like Amane has a complex about her lack\nof dexterity.
Amane and I were doing pilot training using the\nsimulator.
'When turning, if the steering on the rudder is\nreduced, or the timing is too slow, it can cause\nit to slip in.'
'On the other hand, if you use the rudder too\nmuch, or the timing is too fast, it can slip\nout.'
Slipping in or slipping out are the terms used to\nrefer to diagonal movement of the glider.
This is caused when you are trying to turn but\nthe nose is not pointing in the right direction.
'With slipping in or out, the glider no longer\nfaces in the direction of the relative wind,\nwhich causes a reduction in lift.'

That means that if the glider is moving through
the air at a decent speed, even if there is no
wind at all, it is still the same as if it were
taking wind from the direction in which it is
moving.
That is what is known as 'relative wind'.
So, if the glider is moving diagonally, the wind\nhits it diagonally too.
This means, if the glider takes the wind from the\nfront, the functions of that aircraft are\nmaximized.
When Amane says that there will be a 'reduction\nin lift', it's because it cannot take the wind\ndirectly from the front.
'Even without that, lift is reduced when turning\nanyway, so if it slips in or out, you lose a lot\nof speed.'
'Excuse me.'
Akari Kumoi, the vice president of the student\ncouncil entered the garage.
'Hi, vice president.'
'Hello Mochizuki-senpai. Also...'
'Hi.'
Our eyes meet, so I lower my head in a bow.
'Hello, Aoi.'
Akari looks around the garage and nods with\napproval.
'It looks like you are working hard.'
'Yeah. Just like real club activities.'
she says with pride, because these are club\nactivities after all.
'Anyway, do you need something?'
'I just came to see how things are going. Things\nweren't too great last time.'
'As you can see, we are doing very well.'
'Yes, I can see that...'
For some reason, I feel that she has a bit of a\nsharp tongue when talking to me.
It seems like vice president Akari Kumoi is\nlooking at me like she's assessing me.
'(He really does have a trusting face. He doesn't\nseem like a bad guy... but I'd better be\ncareful.)'
'...What is it?'
'No, it's nothing.'
Does she have a problem with me?
Akari heads over to the other two working at the\nback of the garage.
'May I take a look at that?'
'Oh, Akari. Go ahead.'
'...How about this one?'
'Yes, that looks good.'
'That's FRP, isn't it? What are you making?'
'A dish.'
'A dish?'

'We're practicing. We want to make the wings of a
glider but we can't start doing that straight
away because if we mess it up, there'll be
problems.'
'Now we have to wait for it to harden. Then, we\npolish it, then add the color...'
Kotori mumbled to herself as she checked her\nnotes.
'Kotori, once you've finished using the roller\nand the brush, you should wash them quickly.'
'The resin will harden, and you won't be able to\nuse them anymore.'
'Oh, really?'
Kotori hurriedly goes to wash them.
That was a close one, she almost ruined some of\nthe equipment we had just bought.
'Also, the resin mixed with curing agent dries\nmore easily at high temperatures so the container\nshould be put in a cool place in the shade.'
Kotori wiped her wet hands on her skirt, and made\na note of Akari's advice.
'It will take a long time to make the main wings,\nso we have to think about things like that...'
Ageha also looks like she's thinking seriously.
After confirming that the other two were doing\nproper club activities, relieved, she came back\nover to us.
'It's going well, isn't it?'
'Yeah.'
Amane answered proudly. She looked happy to be\npraised like that.
'Anyway, there was actually one other reason I\ncame here.'
'Have you decided a person to be second in\ncharge?'
'Second in charge?'
The other two working at the back of the garage\nstop and turn their attention this way.
'Yes.'
'Mochizuki-senpai, you are very talented but...\nthere may be times when you can't do all of the\nwork yourself, correct?'
'At those times, it's extremely helpful to have\nsomeone like that around.'
Apart from Amane, everyone made a face that\nseemed to say 'Oh, I see'.
It's probably not just Akari, but all the other\nstudent council members in the past would also\nhave had trouble with Amane.
She's very... unique, so sometimes she expresses\nideas that differ from the general social norms.

There was the issue with the club losing its
status the other day, and the fact that she keeps
repeating the year is a prime example of her
uniqueness.
She's trying to say that she would like someone\nto act as a middle-man, to keep things running\nsmoothly, like a manager.
'(But what you really mean, is that you need\nsomeone to act as a mediator, right?)'
From the few days that I have spent with Amane,\nit seems that she isn't suited to being any sort\nof mediator.

She decides the club's principles and therefore,
the reason for it to exist, whereas the second in
charge is needed to bring everyone together to
carry that out.
'OK, I understand. I will choose someone.'
'That would be helpful.'
Akari seemed relieved as she nodded, and then\nglanced at me.
'(...As I thought, she may choose Aoi Minase.)'
'(According to Kanako, he's popular, good at\ntaking action...not bad looking...)'
'(...Oh, what am I thinking!?)'
'Umm...what were you talking about there?'
'Huh?'
'You were saying something about me, and looked\nlike you were glancing over at me...'
'I wasn't looking at you! You're too\nself-conscious, Aoi!'
'I was just looking at the Soaring Club's\nactivities, that's all.'
'Oh, I see... Sorry.'
So, actually, she wasn't just glancing at me, she\nwas staring...
'Well, that's all for now.'
Now that she had finished what she had come to\ndo, Akari left in a hurry...
'EEK!'
On the way out, she tripped over a cardboard box.
'Geez, what's this box doing here!?'
Once more, she went to leave.
'What was that all about?'
'I dunno. Maybe she has a thing for Aoi?'
'Huh!?'
'Ohhhh.'
'Why are you saying that all of a sudden?'
'The vice president was looking at you the whole\ntime.'
'I thought she was looking!'
'So there's something going on?'
'No, there isn't, really! C'mon, let's all get\nback to work!'
I try to get them to drop it, then Ageha and\nKotori return to their work.
'He's blushing a little, isn't he?'
'He is. Akari is pretty though.'
I can hear you...
'Amane, what are you going to do about that thing\nthe vice president was talking about just now?'
'I'm not sure. Is there anyone who wants to do\nit?'
The two other girls look at each other for some\nreason, then look at me.
'Hmm.'
'That's what it looks like.'
'That's what it looks like.'
'You can't decide something like that by saying\n'That's what it looks like'! Let's think about\nthis, Amane!'
'OK, I will.'
she said as I try to reach a resolution to the\nproblem that I had brought up.
'What I mean is that everyone should keep\nmumbling to themselves to a minimum and\nconcentrate on the task at hand.'
'...You sound like the second in charge already.'
'He's surprisingly motivated, isn't he?'
'I think that we should choose Aoi.'
Everyone was muttering to themselves as they got\nback to work.
'It's about time for us to leave.'
'I would've liked to have done a bit more work\nthough. The quicker we complete this, the quicker\nwe can fly it.'
Kotori murmured quietly to herself.
The school closes at 6:30 PM, and if you wish to\nstay longer, you need to submit a notice of\nextension of club activities.
However, I have my dorm mother work to do, Kotori\nhas to help me with dinner, so we have to leave\nat the usual time.
'Tomorrow, while continuing with the dish that we\nwere trying out today, we can start making the\nshape for the main wings!'
'We'll soon be starting the real thing!'
'If we rush it, it will snap again, which will be\na big problem. Let's work on it with all due\ncare.'
'Yeah.'
Today, at lunchtime, things still seemed awkward\nbetween them, but after only half a day has\npassed, they've really opened up to each other.
'By the way, Aoi, what do you think of Akari?'
'Huh?'
'Oh, that's right! I was thinking before that we\nshould cross-examine you about this once club\nactivities had finished!'
'What's this all about? I don't care, you don't\nneed to cross-examine me.'
'In that case, tell us about it!'
'Yeah, tell us!'
I can't believe these two...
'OK, let's make a dash back home! All the\nboarders are waiting with empty stomachs!'
I ran as I pushed Kotori's wheelchair.
'Hey, wait!'
'Why are you covering it up!?'
I thought that somehow, these two might just get\nalong really well.
